position.marginalia_text: L. Valla, quinquaginta Digestorum libros expeditè, curioseq[ue] perlegit suo Marte, Sine ullis glossis, aut doctoribus antiquis, aut nouis. Quid ni alius faciat pari acuite, aut pra[e]gnantiori compendio? Pra[e]sertim subtiliori dialectica, et pra[e]dentiori politica pra[e]munitus, idemq[ue] omni eleganti literatura vel a[e]qualis, vel fortassis instructior. Expedit autem tali Pandectologo, ab istis ordiri analyticis Freigij Paratitlis: tumq[ue] ipsum continuò iuris ciuilis textum verè aureum dialecticè, politicè, iuridicè retexere, intimè examinare, priuatim, publicéq[ue] disputare, assiduissimè repetere: memoria[e] penitùs infigere: nunq[uam] nimis quod nunq[uam] satis. Certè ha[e]c Pandectarum Synopsis instar est adamantini speculi, ad totius iuris Romani corpus, et animam conspicua analyse pra[e]monstrandam. Qua[e] omnium est humanaru[m] professionu[m] Vtilissima, atq[ue] potentissima, non modò prudentissima, et honoratissima. Nec verò vlla ciuilis ars, scientia, aut facultas tanti est in rep. momenti, aut in mundo pretij, quanti ista forensis, et pragmatica disciplina, maximè omnium regia professio. Cui radicitùs enucleandas quadruplici opus analyse, generali logica, speciali politica, particulari iuridica, singulari pragmatica. Tantum nactus Spartam, hanc perornato.

book.title: Paratitla seu synopsis pandectarum iuris ciuilis

marginalia.translation: Lorenzo Valla read quickly and curiously through the fifty books of the 'Digest' on his own, without any glosses, either from ancient or modern scholars. What could another not do with a comparable acuity or more pregnant compendium? Particularly if he were fortified with a more subtle dialectic and more compact politics, and either equally or perhaps better trained in all elegant literature. Instead, in the study of the 'Digest' he rushes from these to begin with Freigius's analytical 'Paratitla'. And then immediately to rework this truly golden text of civil law dialectically, politically and juridically, to examine it intimately, to discuss it publically and privately, and to return to it assiduously. Inwardly, he fixes it in his memory. Never too much, but never enough. Certainly, this synopsis of the 'Digest' is the image of an incorruptible mirror, to be directed, with its striking analysis, at the body and spirit of all Roman law. Of all human professions, this is the most useful and most powerful, as well as wisest and most honourable. Any civil art, science or skill only serves for the progress of the state or the wealth of the world to the extent that it is a public and pragmatic discipline; this is particularly the case when it comes to the king of all professions. Fundamentally, the task involves a fourfold analysis: by general logic, specific policies, particar laws and individual cases. "You are in Sparta; make it splendid."
